Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the low mortality rate in the United States and falsely asserts that it is "just about the best in the world."
Understate: The claim understates the potential impact of the rising number of COVID-19 cases, suggesting that many of the cases are of people who are not sick or only mildly affected.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or data to support the assertion that the low mortality rate is solely due to increased testing.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the increased testing is the only reason for the rise in cases, ignoring other possible explanations such as increased transmission of the virus.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim ignores the possibility that the current upticks in cases may eventually lead to increases in mortality, as suggested by experts.
